author: ixamnis
body:
I see several people on here suggesting VOO.  I have no problem with VOO, but be aware that the top six holdings in VOO are:  AAPL, MSFT, AMZN, FB, GOOGL and GOOG.  I like VOO, but if you want to diversify outside of tech you may want to consider some value stocks and buy individual stocks instead of an ETF, or buy sector ETFs.  

Value stocks that I'd recommend:  ABBV, ACN, AES, CLX, DIS, IBM, JNJ, JPM, KHC, KO, KR, LOW, MA, MAR, MCD, NVS, O, PEP, PFE, PLAY, SBUX, T, TD, TGT, TROW, VZ, WBA, WMT, WSM. I think you could easily pick any three to five of these and have a nicely balanced portfolio given the amount of money you are investing.

Sector ETFs that I like include:

ICLN, TAN or PBW - Clean energy/renewable energy

FHLC, XLV - Health Care

IDNA, ARKG - Genomic Research and DNA technology

PRNT - 3D printing

ARKQ, THNK, ROBO - artificial intelligence and robotics (However, this is "tech")

VFH, FNCL, XLF, IEFN - financial sector ETFs

I'm not a financial advisor and have no business giving financial advice. That said, a nice balanced portfolio might look something like this:

33% tech stocks and ETFs  (This is what you already have)

33% value stocks (from the list above)

33% sector ETFs:  10% ICLN, 10% ARKG, 10% XLV

Best of luck to you.

author: greytoc
body:
>Both are in varying forms of cloud computing

That's not entirely accurate. Both are extremely different businesses with different products that target different customers. It's like saying that $NVO and $HCA are varying forms of healthcare. 

$RXT is a capital intensive business that attempted to compete with AWS, Azure, GCP, and Softlayer/IBM but is considered a small player. They pivoted with software offerings to support multicloud solutions in an attempt to be an overlay solution to companies that require multicloud infrastructure. But I think that's a tough sell to companies that are deploying IaC solutions instead which may be arguably more agile and flexible. 

$SNOW - well - I don't know why the valuation is that high. They have a good product and service and many companies have flocked to them because they are more affordable than AWS Redshift and GCP BigQuery - and they have some nice built in ETL. They seem to have captured a lot of startup tech companies but  I don't really understand how/when they can be profitable. Competing on price alone doesn't seem sustainable to me. 

I don't hold any positions in either company.

author: ZarrCon
body:
Yes, payout ratio is honestly one of the most important factors for people looking at dividend paying stocks. 

For example: MCD has a yield of 2.29% right now and a payout ratio of around 80%. AVGO has a yield of 3.64% with a payout ratio of around 60%. IBM has a yield of 5.46% with a payout ratio of around 60% too. 

So even though IBM has a much larger yield than MCD, they are paying out less of their overall earnings, which I would argue means their dividend is technically safer. That being said, don't invest based on payout ratio or yield alone. Invest in quality companies with good long term prospects, which I'd argue IBM doesn't have.

mPulse is the patented leading microgrid managing software, and mVSO is their optimization program that then feeds info to their mPulse software. Not 100% sure if mVSO is patented but their main product mPulse definitely is.

IBM said they're on the leading edge of the cutting edge in a white paper, and seeing as though tesla partnered with them on a microgrid battery I think it's more set in stone than up in the air. 1m in backlogged contracts, and more projected after the acquisition of gridfabric and its clients.

author: moneygardener
body:
Regarding INTC:

With all the security issues that has been popping up the last couple of years (Meltdown, Spectre and unfortunately many more)

The risk of having fabs that are being outperformed by both TSMC and Samsung.  
As in having fabs becoming a liability if you can't reach the cutting edge.

Losing marketshare in both DIY desktop segment and datacenters. due to the competitors latest 2-3 product cycles which are competitive both in price and performance.

Rumours of terrible workplace conditions, especially for the so-called green badges. (Green badges are hired short-mid term employees)

Hilariously terrible and false marketing lately (Which they are receiving a lot of flak for in the tech tuber space) Possibly why their Chief Communications Officer, Claire Dixon just left.

A freshly started ext-gpu division (Risky. Difficult to compete. A moneyhog if it doesn't work out)

INTC also has a lot of debt.  


All in all I fear that they will be the new IBM of chip stocks.

author: PerilousPostulation
body:
Nvidia has certainly tried tie-ups with a CPU arch for perf gains before - the IBM Power CPUs in the summit supercomputer are directly lashed together with their Nvidia GV100s through a native NVLink interface rather than the usual switch chips

I see why they might prefer to self-build an ARM variant of that concept over Power given the momentum of the ISA in servers and computers. But yeah, just don’t understand why the Apple route isn’t a better way to do it

author: Dogburt_Jr
body:
Because the terms are ill will/anti-competitive/monopolistic. They don't encourage a free market. I agree for >80% of apps in-app payment should go through Google Play. I don't do so for Spotify, I pay through their website. Fortnite is entitled to do the same. Apple only cares because Fortnite is a massive revenue for them because of all the kids using parents credit cards on their iPhones.

I disagree with Apple and Epic Games on a *lot* of their ethics policies. Epic Studios is a massive burnout hell for developers, and their business model is exploiting children under 18 y/o. The bell curve is likely averaged around 13 y/o. Apple holds an overbearing tight key over their software, very comparable to IBM in the early computer days and their business model is blatantly anti-consumer based on the design of a lot of their products and sales model. iPhones are physically the nicest phones to fix. But they will fight with everything they have to prevent repairs by 3rd parties.

I think this is one time I actually like Epic Games.

author: HwanZike
body:
Big companies have issues and risks due to their sheer size. There's also risks of new paradigm shifts. History usually repeats itself, people think companies like FAGMAN will continue to grow and be dominant. Look at how the big ones fell, from railway companies back in the 1900 to more recent history with GM, F, X, AT&T, GE, AIG, C, XOM, ICBC, IBM, to name a few. Who knows what the next big companies will be? Or what sectors? Biotech? Clean energy?

Check this podcast episode that touches on it: https://rationalreminder.ca/podcast/113

author: hungry_koala
body:
Buy index funds. Seriously. know you’re probably thinking you can beat the market. I’ve been investing/trading for almost 3 years and I’ve been there before. I set out with the intention of beating the market, and was successful at some points. Let me tell you I would have better far better off if I just started with building a good foundation (index funds). Now I’m 25 and while I’ve made some good investments ultimately my losses are still weighing me down (that said some of my investment theses have not played out so this can change in the future). To give some more perspective, I’ve been working for 2 years and 4 months and I only have one years worth of max contributions in my 401k, Roth IRA, and HSA, when I could easily have maxed it out this whole time.

Granted this isn’t a terrible position to be in—I’m probably still ahead of many people my age and even some older than me. I’m grateful for this and count my blessings every day. But I’d be so much further along in my journey if I didn’t indulge in so much speculation and gambling (yes even investing in companies like Apple or Microsoft for the long term is not foolproof.. just look back at giants past of the S&P and see where they are today. IBM, XOM, Enron are some classic example). Index funds are truly the only investments you can blindly hold for a long period of time with minimal re evaluation and decision making.

As for what to buy, look for the lowest cost index funds you can find. VOO or VTI are classics. If you have fidelity, they have zero fee equivalents (FNILX,FZROX), which can save you a lot of money over time if you take into account compounding gains. Hope this helps!

author: darqmachine
body: Yes it is. A Reverse Iron Condor is the same as an Iron Condor while a Reverse Iron Butterfly is the opposite of a Butterfly. You use the Butterfly or the Iron Condor on stocks that exhibit a Delta Neutral Pattern as in no movement. Stocks like GE, Ford, Fitbit, Gopro, IBM have been stagnant over the past 2 or 3 months. On these they are perfect for Condors or Butterflies because the stay within a certain price range. On these you want to look at the the Greeks I mentioned earlier and then look at the Vix.

author: honor-
body:
>Well artificial intelligence is used in -Vaccine research -Cyber security -medicine -computer programming -Mass Production of good

You seem to have a very limited understanding of current capabilities of AI. But let me keep it simple: AI can not think or reason, it is only used for limited tasks that involve crunching huge amounts of data that humans cannot. Now you need to ask yourself the question of whether or not IBM can do this for profit and grow their sales of AI services.

&#x200B;

>Because of covid 19 I don’t think big corporate companies are going to want humans they are expensive and are snowflakes. There for most major companies will be more inclined to robots and artificial intelligence

OK, among AI professionals IBM Watson is kinda considered a joke that did good at Jeopardy and nothing else. It's tried to expand into health but very few hospitals take it, and even then its only used in limited capacity to evaluate its judgements. I haven't heard of it being used widely, and there are certainly no clinical studies that have been done to evaluate any improvements over human professionals. Just the clinical study part should give you massive pause.

&#x200B;

>Plus you don’t have to pay taxes for employing artificial intelligence🤷🏼

I don't even know what this means. No one is close to using Watson to replace human workers in anything.

&#x200B;

>Edit: I’m not saying buy the stock because I actually waiting for the dip I’m hoping the stock won’t go up but down

IBM has been in decline for 8 years in spite of massive share buybacks. Their acquisitions have been garbage and they're a garbage company. They will need a total overhauling as a company if they want to have growth in the future.

&#x200B;

>Edit: When you walk down the street do you see IBM on the street or when you drive or when you go to the store no they are not a consumer goods product but corporate product. Pandemic happens corporations cut costs and restructure most companies will want to have less human work force thus AI will take over go to Walmart and look at the self checkout or when you go to a amazon warehouse tell me what you see boy.

Again, no one is using IBM's crappy Watson AI. They're making their own AI solutions.

author: Itsawhazzyitsawhoozy
body:
I bought some stock on June 1st, not the best day price wise but it’s the stock I plan to hold the longest out of my whole portfolio, except for MSFT maybe. I made a DD for myself and made a brief summary around April. Most of it is based on their 10-K last year and their first 10-Q of the year. The key here is that this has been seen as a dinosaur for the past decade, due to lack of innovation, terrible management decisions (crazy high EPS and a buyback program that should have been cut long ago), and recruiting issues. A new CEO (Arvind Krishna) and a switch to the cloud (and quantum computing for the 2030s at least) are the key changes that could drive change. Sorry if it’s a bit messy, was not meant to be posted when I wrote it : 

IBM : New CEO Arvid Krishna has my trust, hope he will change top and mid tier management (which did weird accounting tricks like the pseudo Lenovo « sale/buy », laid off workforce for no reason, did not R&D enough, focused on business services and consulting too much, had the crazy 20$ EPS goal, etc…). Krishna pushed Red Hat acquisition (open source enterprise software, will allow them to become hybrid cloud providers, hybrid cloud is interoperable (BFF example), scalable (ERP switch to 3rd parties), portable, and secure (user data still in private cloud)). Krishna was senior VP for cloud and cognitive software. 
IBM has switched industries several times throughout its life : time clocks, then tabulating machine, then typewriter, then mainframe (good changes), then personal computers (good initially but then poor because used competitors’ chips), etc… Cloud/AI could be their next successful switch (1/3rd of revenue in 2019, still increasing). Quantum Computing too, as they’ve strongly positioned themselves as industry leaders, but that’s in the very, very long run.
While not the most important aspect, company is a dividend aristocrat (increasing div payout for 25 years), but what matters is that div payment was never removed, even though I think it should have been decreased during the struggles of the 2010s and instead reinvested in R&D, they should have also paused their share buyback program. Financials : P/E around 10 (very good for a tech company), P/BV is 5.5 (good for a tech company, especially one transitioning to less tangible assets), net income slowly increasing, current ratio of nearly 1 at end of 03/31 which is decent given Red Hat acquisition and coronavirus, D/E is 2.62 (that one is indeed bad, but they got cash I guess, still not great).

author: bitflag
body:
I think Intel is already close to being IBM. They consistently gave up on new markets (ie mobile, high end GPU, modems) because it is initially small and expensive, which let the competition take those juicy new trends while Intel got stuck the same old x86 chips it's been doing for 4 decades.

Manufacturing problems is only salt on the wound. It's accelerating the decline because it was Intel moat in it's core business.

author: HallucinatoryFrog
body:
Bit of a personal anecdote here:

So I have a degree in IT with a focus on Computer Networking.

I once interviewed for IBM because they had positions open for Network Admins.  Unfortunately, when I sat down and looked over their list of jobs I discovered that they were only looking for senior level positions (something they did not mention in the email they sent to my university).

I decided to interview anyway because I was already there in suit and tie so I wasn't about to get all dressed up for nothing.

The interview went well, but the guy told me he just didn't have anything for me at the time.

I decided to walk around afterwards and saw a guy interviewing for entry level programmers.  My campus did not offer a Software degree (they offered it at a different campus), but I did have to take 9 credits in basic programming which was Java, C++, and HTML.  I had already taken the Java and C++ classes.

I sit down with the guy and we get to talking.

He asks my background in coding.  I tell him one intro in Java and C++ so far.

He asks why am I interviewing if my degree is not focused on coding.  I tell him because those two classes opened my eyes to something that I didn't even know I wanted before.  I love creating stuff with code, I find it cathartic to sit and stare at code, getting lost in it while trying to figure out where my errors are, the absolute joy of finally getting it to compile and run.  I even started to make some basic programs at home in my free time.

He asks me if I have any of my work to show him.  I did not bring any copies of my code because I wasn't even thinking about the possibility of interviewing for any other positions (let this be a lesson to anyone who's still getting their degree, bring everything!).

I tell him I did have it on a thumb drive that I carry around in my briefcase, but of course he waves his hand and says that's a security issue (totally agreed).

He asks me what a function is.  I draw a blank.  I ended up stammering out something like, "it's the part of the code that does stuff".  Not necessarily wrong, but more of an ELI5 definition.

He shows me some code and asks what I can decipher from it.  It's a function that takes a variable, runs it through a formula, returns a variable, and then loops 4 more times using the new return variable each time, and finally shows a set of the return variables at the print out.  He confirmed that I was right.

He asks me what that sets of numbers is called.  Obviously it's an array, and I had heard the term before, but again I did not know at the time.  He frowns and says something along the lines of, "You really don't know basic terminology.  You should work on that."

We shook hands and parted ways, never got a call back.  Now, I know I messed up by not having some of my work printed out, and not being up on the terminology.  But it really rubbed me raw that this guy was so hung up on terminology, knowing that coding was like 5% of my entire degree, and yet I still had a basic working knowledge of programming to at least be able to read and understand what was going on, and that I was passionate enough about it to go home and write some basic programs of my own.

Now I don't know that the lack of terminology was the ultimate reason I was turned down.  I do know that they were looking to start up a class that would take about 3 years to go through, and they were going to teach a proprietary language that was similar to Java.  Obviously, the terminology would have been brought up again multiple times in that 3 year program.  The only clue I had for why I was turned down was the lack of lingo.

I am now a manager at a FinTech company, and I don't ask "lingo" questions of interviewees.  I want to know if they understand the meat and potatoes of what the job entails because, to me, that means so much more.  Lingo will happen over time as they do the job.

I'm not saying that is all the OP was concerned about in their interviews, but they certainly seem to think it's a flaw in an interviewee that makes them unsuitable for hiring.

author: Lazybumm1
body:
I'm very bullish on NVIDIA but I think you are overestimating some of its competitive advantages. Raytracing will probably become industry standard sooner or later and supported across either platform. DLSS is something AMD or any other company with a bunch of ML engineers and money can replicate given some time. 

It's not impossible for other companies to replicate or immitate or substitute some of those technologies / products. AMD is certainly catching up and will carve off some fractions of the market in the AI/ML & datacenter businesses.

The ARM acquisition, if it happens, will confer a competitive advantage like no other. As an NVDA stockholder I wish this happens. As a Brit working in and loving tech, I am slowly dying on the inside... 

Something to remember is that this is a fast expanding market and not a saturated one, there's room for multiple players to grow and win at the same time. 

That being said, I still think Intel will likely be the next IBM. Is it gonna tank overnight? No, and there will probably be plenty of rallies to make money off, but long term I wouldn't look to hold.

author: HallucinatoryFrog
body:
I trim profit and move it into VTI.  I don't trust any individual company, or even most other ETFs, to be around and at a higher price in the next 30 years.

Don't trust any of them, not even the FNMAGA stocks.  You can go all the way back to RCA, F, GM, GE...up to INTC, CSCO, IBM...really any time period since stocks have been traded and find plenty of examples of companies that became value traps for investors.

The broad markets continue to go up and are the closest thing to a guarantee you will probably find in the stock market.

Where I live i am not legally allowed to trade in the stocks. But recently few new web services has allowed me. Almost everyday i would think about investing in the us stocks but I had to settle for stocks in my own country. I did lot of study my thesis everything on this topic. So on 22/06/2020 i started. Not a great time to enter. Made few mistakes at the beginning because of excitement.

I can't predict every ups and downs. This one is very similar to 1999/2000. Check CSCO and QCOM chart for the period. You will see amazing similarity. And if you are asking why these stocks they were the market leaders of the time and their split marked the beginning of a bear market.

author: sleepyguy007
body:
intel, cisco, qualcomm, juniper etc were all huge bubble stocks in the tech bubble and were making tons of money.  


This tech bubble is just as bad and the same sort of mix of unprofitable companies, profitable overvalued companies, and now people just trying to cash out as fast as possible via SPACs and IPOs as there was then.  It might not be quite as steep a bubble yet, but its definitely getting there.  it took 4 years to go from 1200 -> 5000 in 2000.   4 years ago the nasdaq was 5000 or so, so I could see it gettingto even 15000 and then crashing.  maybe not quite as big, but still as someone above mentioned economic conditions are far far worse now and we have much more debt than we did in 2000 as a nation
